title: 109_hr5939
content: The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" may be cited as the short title. This act includes provisions related to terrorist offenses resulting in death. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" includes a new offense related to terrorist offenses resulting in death. It amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, by adding a section that punishes individuals who cause death in the course of committing a terrorist offense. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" adds a new offense related to terrorist acts resulting in death under Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code. It includes penalties for individuals who cause death while committing a terrorist offense. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces a new offense for terrorist acts resulting in death, with penalties for individuals who cause death while committing a terrorist offense. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces amendments to various sections of the United States Code, allowing for the death penalty in cases involving nuclear threats, missile systems, atomic weapons, radiological dispersal devices, and the variola virus. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN CERTAIN PENALTIES. Amends penalties in various sections of title 18, United States Code, increasing from 20 to 30 years and from 10 to 20 years. SEC. 5. MODERNIZATION OF STATE OF MIND REQUIREMENT FOR SECTION 2339C OFFENSES. Changes the requirement from "unlawfully and wilfully" to "knowingly." SEC. 6. PROVIDING MATERIAL SUPPORT TO TERRORIST GROUPS. SEC. 5. MODERNIZATION OF STATE OF MIND REQUIREMENT FOR SECTION 2339C OFFENSES. Amends Section 2339C of title 18, United States Code, by changing the requirement from "unlawfully and wilfully" to "knowingly." SEC. 6. PROVIDING MATERIAL SUPPORT TO TERRORIST GROUPS. Amends penalties for providing material support to terrorists and receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization. SEC. 7 amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code to deny Federal benefits to individuals convicted of Federal terrorism crimes. It defines 'Federal benefit' and specifies the ineligibility for benefits upon conviction. SEC. 8 amends Section 2516(q) of title 18, US Code by updating wiretap predicates. SEC. 9 modifies Section 2339D by including attempts or conspiracies related to military training offenses.
